title: Spongiotic osteoma in the external auditory canal: Two cases of a rare\ntumor
patient:
A 19-year-old man visited our otorhinolaryngology clinic with a known mass in the right
EAC. He had reported mild symptoms with aural fullness for several years. On physical
examination, an ovoid hard mass was observed in the right EAC (). Temporal bone computed tomography
revealed a 0.6 cm × 0.5 cm anterior-based, pedunculated, bony mass originating from the
tympanosquamous suture line (). Because the tumor was of bone origin, surgical excision was planned.
As in Case 1, surgery was performed, and pathology revealed a spongiotic osteoma (). Two years and five
months after surgery, the patient is without symptoms and there has been no tumor
recurrence.
